</table><h2>
<a id="user-content-asymptotics" class="anchor" href="#asymptotics" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Asymptotics</h2>

<ul>
<li>Asymptotics is the term for the behavior of statistics as the sample size (or some other relevant quantity) limits to infinity (or some other relevant number)</li>
<li>(Asymptopia is my name for the land of asymptotics, where everything works out well and there's no messes. The land of infinite data is nice that way.)</li>
<li>Asymptotics are incredibly useful for simple statistical inference and approximations </li>
<li>(Not covered in this class) Asymptotics often lead to nice understanding of procedures</li>
<li>Asymptotics generally give no assurances about finite sample performance</li>
<li>Asymptotics form the basis for frequency interpretation of probabilities 
(the long run proportion of times an event occurs)</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-limits-of-random-variables" class="anchor" href="#limits-of-random-variables" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Limits of random variables</h2>

<ul>
<li>Fortunately, for the sample mean there's a set of powerful results</li>
<li>These results allow us to talk about the large sample distribution
of sample means of a collection of $iid$ observations</li>
<li>The first of these results we intuitively know

<ul>
<li>It says that the average limits to what it's estimating, the population mean</li>
<li>It's called the Law of Large Numbers</li>
<li>Example $\bar X_n$ could be the average of the result of $n$ coin flips (i.e. the sample proportion of heads)

<ul>
<li>As we flip a fair coin over and over, it eventually converges to the
true probability of a head
The LLN forms the basis of frequency style thinking</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-law-of-large-numbers-in-action" class="anchor" href="#law-of-large-numbers-in-action" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Law of large numbers in action</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>n &lt;- 10000; means &lt;- cumsum(rnorm(n)) / (1  : n); library(ggplot2)
g &lt;- ggplot(data.frame(x = 1 : n, y = means), aes(x = x, y = y)) 
g &lt;- g + geom_hline(yintercept = 0) + geom_line(size = 2) 
g &lt;- g + labs(x = "Number of obs", y = "Cumulative mean")
g
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-law-of-large-numbers-in-action-coin-flip" class="anchor" href="#law-of-large-numbers-in-action-coin-flip" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Law of large numbers in action, coin flip</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>means &lt;- cumsum(sample(0 : 1, n , replace = TRUE)) / (1  : n)
g &lt;- ggplot(data.frame(x = 1 : n, y = means), aes(x = x, y = y)) 
g &lt;- g + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5) + geom_line(size = 2) 
g &lt;- g + labs(x = "Number of obs", y = "Cumulative mean")
g
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-discussion" class="anchor" href="#discussion" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Discussion</h2>

<ul>
<li>An estimator is <strong>consistent</strong> if it converges to what you want to estimate

<ul>
<li>The LLN says that the sample mean of iid sample is
consistent for the population mean</li>
<li>Typically, good estimators are consistent; it's not too much to ask that if we go to the trouble of collecting an infinite amount of data that we get the right answer</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The sample variance and the sample standard deviation
of iid random variables are consistent as well</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-the-central-limit-theorem" class="anchor" href="#the-central-limit-theorem" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>The Central Limit Theorem</h2>

<ul>
<li>The <strong>Central Limit Theorem</strong> (CLT) is one of the most important theorems in statistics</li>
<li>For our purposes, the CLT states that the distribution of averages of iid variables (properly normalized) becomes that of a standard normal as the sample size increases</li>
<li>The CLT applies in an endless variety of settings</li>
<li>The result is that 
$$\frac{\bar X_n - \mu}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}}=
\frac{\sqrt n (\bar X_n - \mu)}{\sigma}
= \frac{\mbox{Estimate} - \mbox{Mean of estimate}}{\mbox{Std. Err. of estimate}}$$ has a distribution like that of a standard normal for large $n$.</li>
<li>(Replacing the standard error by its estimated value doesn't change the CLT)</li>
<li>The useful way to think about the CLT is that 
$\bar X_n$ is approximately
$N(\mu, \sigma^2 / n)$</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-example" class="anchor" href="#example" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Example</h2>

<ul>
<li>Simulate a standard normal random variable by rolling $n$ (six sided)</li>
<li>Let $X_i$ be the outcome for die $i$</li>
<li>Then note that $\mu = E[X_i] = 3.5$</li>
<li>$Var(X_i) = 2.92$ </li>
<li>SE $\sqrt{2.92 / n} = 1.71 / \sqrt{n}$</li>
<li>Let's roll $n$ dice, take their mean, subtract off 3.5,
and divide by $1.71 / \sqrt{n}$ and repeat this over and over</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-result-of-our-die-rolling-experiment" class="anchor" href="#result-of-our-die-rolling-experiment" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Result of our die rolling experiment</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>nosim &lt;- 1000
cfunc &lt;- function(x, n) sqrt(n) * (mean(x) - 3.5) / 1.71
dat &lt;- data.frame(
  x = c(apply(matrix(sample(1 : 6, nosim * 10, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 10),
        apply(matrix(sample(1 : 6, nosim * 20, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 20),
        apply(matrix(sample(1 : 6, nosim * 30, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 30)
        ),
  size = factor(rep(c(10, 20, 30), rep(nosim, 3))))
g &lt;- ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, fill = size)) + geom_histogram(alpha = .20, binwidth=.3, colour = "black", aes(y = ..density..)) 
g &lt;- g + stat_function(fun = dnorm, size = 2)
g + facet_grid(. ~ size)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-coin-clt" class="anchor" href="#coin-clt" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Coin CLT</h2>

<ul>
<li>Let $X_i$ be the $0$ or $1$ result of the $i^{th}$ flip of a possibly unfair coin</li>
<li>The sample proportion, say $\hat p$, is the average of the coin flips</li>
<li>$E[X_i] = p$ and $Var(X_i) = p(1-p)$</li>
<li>Standard error of the mean is $\sqrt{p(1-p)/n}$</li>
<li>Then
$$
\frac{\hat p - p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)/n}}
$$
will be approximately normally distributed</li>
<li>Let's flip a coin $n$ times, take the sample proportion
of heads, subtract off .5 and multiply the result by
$2 \sqrt{n}$ (divide by $1/(2 \sqrt{n})$)</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-simulation-results" class="anchor" href="#simulation-results" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Simulation results</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>nosim &lt;- 1000
cfunc &lt;- function(x, n) 2 * sqrt(n) * (mean(x) - 0.5) 
dat &lt;- data.frame(
  x = c(apply(matrix(sample(0:1, nosim * 10, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 10),
        apply(matrix(sample(0:1, nosim * 20, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 20),
        apply(matrix(sample(0:1, nosim * 30, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 30)
        ),
  size = factor(rep(c(10, 20, 30), rep(nosim, 3))))
g &lt;- ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, fill = size)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=.3, colour = "black", aes(y = ..density..)) 
g &lt;- g + stat_function(fun = dnorm, size = 2)
g + facet_grid(. ~ size)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-simulation-results-p--09" class="anchor" href="#simulation-results-p--09" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Simulation results, $p = 0.9$</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>nosim &lt;- 1000
cfunc &lt;- function(x, n) sqrt(n) * (mean(x) - 0.9) / sqrt(.1 * .9)
dat &lt;- data.frame(
  x = c(apply(matrix(sample(0:1, prob = c(.1,.9), nosim * 10, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 10),
        apply(matrix(sample(0:1, prob = c(.1,.9), nosim * 20, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 20),
        apply(matrix(sample(0:1, prob = c(.1,.9), nosim * 30, replace = TRUE), 
                     nosim), 1, cfunc, 30)
        ),
  size = factor(rep(c(10, 20, 30), rep(nosim, 3))))
g &lt;- ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, fill = size)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=.3, colour = "black", aes(y = ..density..)) 
g &lt;- g + stat_function(fun = dnorm, size = 2)
g + facet_grid(. ~ size)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-galtons-quincunx" class="anchor" href="#galtons-quincunx" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Galton's quincunx</h2>

<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bean_machine#mediaviewer/File:Quincunx_(Galton_Box)_-_Galton_1889_diagram.png">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bean_machine#mediaviewer/File:Quincunx_(Galton_Box)_-_Galton_1889_diagram.png</a></p>

<p><a href="/bcaffo/courses/blob/master/06_StatisticalInference/07_Asymptopia/fig/quincunx.png" target="_blank"><img src="/bcaffo/courses/raw/master/06_StatisticalInference/07_Asymptopia/fig/quincunx.png" height="450" style="max-width:100%;"></a></p>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-confidence-intervals" class="anchor" href="#confidence-intervals" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Confidence intervals</h2>

<ul>
<li>According to the CLT, the sample mean, $\bar X$, 
is approximately normal with mean $\mu$ and sd $\sigma / \sqrt{n}$</li>
<li>$\mu + 2 \sigma /\sqrt{n}$ is pretty far out in the tail
(only 2.5% of a normal being larger than 2 sds in the tail)</li>
<li>Similarly, $\mu - 2 \sigma /\sqrt{n}$ is pretty far in the left tail (only 2.5% chance of a normal being smaller than 2 sds in the tail)</li>
<li>So the probability $\bar X$ is bigger than $\mu + 2 \sigma / \sqrt{n}$
or smaller than $\mu - 2 \sigma / \sqrt{n}$ is 5%

<ul>
<li>Or equivalently, the probability of being between these limits is 95%</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The quantity $\bar X \pm 2 \sigma /\sqrt{n}$ is called
a 95% interval for $\mu$</li>
<li>The 95% refers to the fact that if one were to repeatedly
get samples of size $n$, about 95% of the intervals obtained
would contain $\mu$</li>
<li>The 97.5th quantile is 1.96 (so I rounded to 2 above)</li>
<li>90% interval you want (100 - 90) / 2 = 5% in each tail 

<ul>
<li>So you want the 95th percentile (1.645)</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-give-a-confidence-interval-for-the-average-height-of-sons" class="anchor" href="#give-a-confidence-interval-for-the-average-height-of-sons" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Give a confidence interval for the average height of sons</h2>

<p>in Galton's data</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">UsingR</span>);data(<span class="pl-smi">father.son</span>); <span class="pl-smi">x</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">father.son</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">sheight</span>
(mean(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> c(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sd(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> sqrt(length(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>))) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-c1">12</span></pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-sample-proportions" class="anchor" href="#sample-proportions" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Sample proportions</h2>

<ul>
<li>In the event that each $X_i$ is $0$ or $1$ with common success probability $p$ then $\sigma^2 = p(1 - p)$</li>
<li>The interval takes the form
$$
\hat p \pm z_{1 - \alpha/2}  \sqrt{\frac{p(1 - p)}{n}}
$$</li>
<li>Replacing $p$ by $\hat p$ in the standard error results in what is called a Wald confidence interval for $p$</li>
<li>For 95% intervals
$$\hat p \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}$$ 
is a quick CI estimate for $p$</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-example-1" class="anchor" href="#example-1" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Example</h2>

<ul>
<li>Your campaign advisor told you that in a random sample of 100 likely voters,
56 intent to vote for you. 

<ul>
<li>Can you relax? Do you have this race in the bag?</li>
<li>Without access to a computer or calculator, how precise is this estimate?</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<code>1/sqrt(100)=0.1</code> so a back of the envelope calculation gives an approximate 95% interval of <code>(0.46, 0.66)</code>

<ul>
<li>Not enough for you to relax, better go do more campaigning!</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Rough guidelines, 100 for 1 decimal place, 10,000 for 2, 1,000,000 for 3.</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>round(<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">/</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-c1">10</span> <span class="pl-k">^</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">6</span>)), <span class="pl-c1">3</span>)</pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-binomial-interval" class="anchor" href="#binomial-interval" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Binomial interval</h2>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>.<span class="pl-c1">56</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> c(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(.<span class="pl-c1">56</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> .<span class="pl-c1">44</span> <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-c1">100</span>)
binom.test(<span class="pl-c1">56</span>, <span class="pl-c1">100</span>)<span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">conf.int</span></pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-simulation" class="anchor" href="#simulation" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Simulation</h2>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">n</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">20</span>; <span class="pl-smi">pvals</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> seq(.<span class="pl-c1">1</span>, .<span class="pl-c1">9</span>, <span class="pl-v">by</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> .<span class="pl-c1">05</span>); <span class="pl-smi">nosim</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">1000</span>
<span class="pl-smi">coverage</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sapply(<span class="pl-smi">pvals</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">p</span>){
  <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> rbinom(<span class="pl-smi">nosim</span>, <span class="pl-v">prob</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span>, <span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>
  <span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
  <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
  mean(<span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span> <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span>)
})
</pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-plot-of-the-results-not-so-good" class="anchor" href="#plot-of-the-results-not-so-good" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Plot of the results (not so good)</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>ggplot(data.frame(pvals, coverage), aes(x = pvals, y = coverage)) + geom_line(size = 2) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.95) + ylim(.75, 1.0)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-whats-happening" class="anchor" href="#whats-happening" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>What's happening?</h2>

<ul>
<li>$n$ isn't large enough for the CLT to be applicable
for many of the values of $p$</li>
<li>Quick fix, form the interval with 
$$
\frac{X + 2}{n + 4}
$$</li>
<li>(Add two successes and failures, Agresti/Coull interval)</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-simulation-1" class="anchor" href="#simulation-1" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Simulation</h2>

<p>First let's show that coverage gets better with $n$</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">n</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">100</span>; <span class="pl-smi">pvals</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> seq(.<span class="pl-c1">1</span>, .<span class="pl-c1">9</span>, <span class="pl-v">by</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> .<span class="pl-c1">05</span>); <span class="pl-smi">nosim</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">1000</span>
<span class="pl-smi">coverage2</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sapply(<span class="pl-smi">pvals</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">p</span>){
  <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> rbinom(<span class="pl-smi">nosim</span>, <span class="pl-v">prob</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span>, <span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>
  <span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
  <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
  mean(<span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span> <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span>)
})
</pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-plot-of-coverage-for-n100" class="anchor" href="#plot-of-coverage-for-n100" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Plot of coverage for $n=100$</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>ggplot(data.frame(pvals, coverage), aes(x = pvals, y = coverage2)) + geom_line(size = 2) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.95)+ ylim(.75, 1.0)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-simulation-2" class="anchor" href="#simulation-2" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Simulation</h2>

<p>Now let's look at $n=20$ but adding 2 successes and failures</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">n</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">20</span>; <span class="pl-smi">pvals</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> seq(.<span class="pl-c1">1</span>, .<span class="pl-c1">9</span>, <span class="pl-v">by</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> .<span class="pl-c1">05</span>); <span class="pl-smi">nosim</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">1000</span>
<span class="pl-smi">coverage</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sapply(<span class="pl-smi">pvals</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">p</span>){
  <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> (rbinom(<span class="pl-smi">nosim</span>, <span class="pl-v">prob</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span>, <span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> (<span class="pl-smi">n</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-c1">4</span>)
  <span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
  <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">phats</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">phats</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
  mean(<span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span> <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">p</span>)
})</pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-adding-2-successes-and-2-failures" class="anchor" href="#adding-2-successes-and-2-failures" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Adding 2 successes and 2 failures</h2>

<p>(It's a little conservative)</p>

<pre lang="r,"><code>ggplot(data.frame(pvals, coverage), aes(x = pvals, y = coverage)) + geom_line(size = 2) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.95)+ ylim(.75, 1.0)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-poisson-interval" class="anchor" href="#poisson-interval" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Poisson interval</h2>

<ul>
<li>A nuclear pump failed 5 times out of 94.32 days, give a 95% confidence interval for the failure rate per day?</li>
<li>$X \sim Poisson(\lambda t)$.</li>
<li>Estimate $\hat \lambda = X/t$</li>
<li>$Var(\hat \lambda) = \lambda / t$ </li>
<li>$\hat \lambda / t$ is our variance estimate</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-r-code" class="anchor" href="#r-code" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>R code</h2>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">x</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">5</span>; <span class="pl-smi">t</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">94.32</span>; <span class="pl-smi">lambda</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">x</span> <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">t</span>
round(<span class="pl-smi">lambda</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> c(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">lambda</span> <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">t</span>), <span class="pl-c1">3</span>)
poisson.test(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>, <span class="pl-c1">T</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">94.32</span>)<span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">conf</span></pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-simulating-the-poisson-coverage-rate" class="anchor" href="#simulating-the-poisson-coverage-rate" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Simulating the Poisson coverage rate</h2>

<p>Let's see how this interval performs for lambda
values near what we're estimating</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">lambdavals</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> seq(<span class="pl-c1">0.005</span>, <span class="pl-c1">0.10</span>, <span class="pl-v">by</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> .<span class="pl-c1">01</span>); <span class="pl-smi">nosim</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">1000</span>
<span class="pl-smi">t</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">100</span>
<span class="pl-smi">coverage</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sapply(<span class="pl-smi">lambdavals</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">lambda</span>){
  <span class="pl-smi">lhats</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> rpois(<span class="pl-smi">nosim</span>, <span class="pl-v">lambda</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">lambda</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> <span class="pl-smi">t</span>) <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">t</span>
  <span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">lhats</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">lhats</span> <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">t</span>)
  <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">lhats</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> qnorm(.<span class="pl-c1">975</span>) <span class="pl-k">*</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">lhats</span> <span class="pl-k">/</span> <span class="pl-smi">t</span>)
  mean(<span class="pl-smi">ll</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">lambda</span> <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> <span class="pl-smi">ul</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">lambda</span>)
})</pre></div>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-covarage" class="anchor" href="#covarage" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Covarage</h2>

<p>(Gets really bad for small values of lambda)</p>

<pre lang="r,"><code>ggplot(data.frame(lambdavals, coverage), aes(x = lambdavals, y = coverage)) + geom_line(size = 2) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.95)+ylim(0, 1.0)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-what-if-we-increase-t-to-1000" class="anchor" href="#what-if-we-increase-t-to-1000" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>What if we increase t to 1000?</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>lambdavals &lt;- seq(0.005, 0.10, by = .01); nosim &lt;- 1000
t &lt;- 1000
coverage &lt;- sapply(lambdavals, function(lambda){
  lhats &lt;- rpois(nosim, lambda = lambda * t) / t
  ll &lt;- lhats - qnorm(.975) * sqrt(lhats / t)
  ul &lt;- lhats + qnorm(.975) * sqrt(lhats / t)
  mean(ll &lt; lambda &amp; ul &gt; lambda)
})
ggplot(data.frame(lambdavals, coverage), aes(x = lambdavals, y = coverage)) + geom_line(size = 2) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.95) + ylim(0, 1.0)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-summary" class="anchor" href="#summary" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Summary</h2>

<ul>
<li>The LLN states that averages of iid samples 
converge to the population means that they are estimating</li>
<li>The CLT states that averages are approximately normal, with
distributions

<ul>
<li>centered at the population mean </li>
<li>with standard deviation equal to the standard error of the mean</li>
<li>CLT gives no guarantee that $n$ is large enough</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Taking the mean and adding and subtracting the relevant
normal quantile times the SE yields a confidence interval for the mean

<ul>
<li>Adding and subtracting 2 SEs works for 95% intervals</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Confidence intervals get wider as the coverage increases
(why?)</li>
<li>Confidence intervals get narrower with less variability or
larger sample sizes</li>
<li>The Poisson and binomial case have exact intervals that
don't require the CLT

<ul>
<li>But a quick fix for small sample size binomial calculations is to add 2 successes and failures</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</article>
